results.title: Proofreading & editing skills: spelling and usage. Vol.3
results.brief_description: This video seminar presentation led by Debra Smith and Helen Sutton looks at spelling and usage of words in the pursuit of achieving total accuracy in written communication. Areas covered include: a fun test to see how good your spelling is; how and when to use your computer’s spellchecker; capitalisation rules; when to use numbers and when to use words (50 or fifty); 200 frequently misspelled words; frequently misused words; the most commonly confused pairs of words and a proofreading post-test to see how much you’ve learnt.

results.title: Proofreading & editing skills: grammar and punctuation. Vol.2
results.brief_description: Led by Debra Smith and Helen Sutton, this seminar presentation video aims at teaching how to achieving total accuracy in written communication. This volume concentrates on: a basic review of sentence structure; how to fix run-on sentences; subject/verb agreement rules; noun/pronoun agreement rules; who vs. whom, me vs. myself; essential rules for using commas; use of semicolons; dashes and parentheses; and when to use quotations.

results.title: Proofreading & editing skills: grammar and punctuation. Vol.1
results.brief_description: This live video seminar presentation with Debra Smith and Helen Sutton begins with a one-page pre-test to determine your current proofreading accuracy. By the end of the program you’ll be able to see and measure your improvement! Some of the skills learned include: spotting common typographical errors; how to correct writing without changing the meaning; overcoming monotony and staying alert when proofreading; creating distance from your work so you can coorect your own errors; how to use proofreader’s marks for consistency and time saving and how to stay alert and accurate.

results.title: Proof of power
results.brief_description: Sponsored by the Ford Motor Company, this film deals with the scientific measurement of tractor power, and its application in primary production. The American sequence is included by courtesy of the University of Nebraska, USA.

results.title: Proof (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: House and Moorhouse Films, Lynda House and Jocelyn Moorhouse
results.brief_description: Winner of 7 Australian Film Institute awards, “Proof” is a provocative and engrossing film about a man’s obsessive search for truth. Martin (Hugo Weaving) has been blind from birth. He trusts no-one, except for the camera which has replaced his eyes. His photos are proof that the world he senses is the same as other people see. Then he meets a young kitchen hand, Andy, whose honesty and kindness allow Martin to trust for the first time - until Martin’s jealous housekeeper, Celia, sets out to destroy this relationship. Written and directed by Jocelyn Moorhouse who won a 1992 Victorian Premier’s Literary Award for her screenplay.

results.title: Proof
results.creator_credit: House and Moorhouse Films, Film Victoria, Australian Film Commission, Lynda House and Jocelyn Moorhouse
results.brief_description: Winner of 7 Australian Film Institute awards, “Proof” is a provocative and engrossing film about a man’s obsessive search for truth. Martin (Hugo Weaving) has been blind from birth. He trusts no-one, except for the camera which has replaced his eyes. His photos are proof that the world he senses is the same as other people see. Then he meets a young kitchen hand, Andy, whose honesty and kindness allow Martin to trust for the first time - until Martin’s jealous housekeeper, Celia, sets out to destroy this relationship. Written and directed by Jocelyn Moorhouse who won a 1992 Victorian Premier’s Literary Award for her screenplay. Cast also includes Genevieve Picot, Russell Crowe, heather Mitchell, Jeffrey Walker, Saskia Post, Frankie J. Holden.

results.title: Promotion by-pass
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Office Supervisor’s Problems”.
The office manager has been called on to make a recommendation for promotion and decides on a younger employee because of his ability to get on with people. The older man who has been with the company for fifteen years is passed over. He is disgruntled and resigns although the supervisor tries to explain the situation to him. Discussion is on the question of whether the office manager was right to make the decision that he did.
